entry.title: Derivative principle and rules
entry.content:
Made this during the anticipatory period during June 2023 till before I enter university. It gavve me deeper understanding of calculus and made foundation calculus course a lot easier üòé

$$\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}=f‚Äô(x)$$

Measures best constant approximation for rate of change (at one point)

dy : change in y
dx : change in x

Derivative rules

Accuracy increases as the small change in x approaches zero.

First principle$$f‚Äô(x)=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h}$$

limit of h to 0 : h infinitely approaches 0
f(x+h) : function value after the change in x
f(x) : initial value of function
h : change in x

setting h -> 0 simplify problem
knowing first principle is useful in proving formulas

L‚ÄôH√¥pital‚Äôs rule (actually Bernoulli)$$\lim_{h\rightarrow0}\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}=\lim_{h\rightarrow0}\frac{f‚Äô(x)}{g‚Äô(x)}$$

Power rule$$\frac{\mathrm{d}(x^n) }{\mathrm{d} x}=nx^{n-1}$$

Reciprocal rule$$f^{-1}(x)=-\frac{f‚Äô(x)}{f(x)^2}$$

Sum rule$$\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}(g(x)+h(x))=g‚Äô(x) + h‚Äô(x)$$

One by one, straightforward

Chain rule$$\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}g(h(x))=\frac{\mathrm{d}g }{\mathrm{d}h}(h(x))\frac{\mathrm{d} h}{\mathrm{d} x}(x)$$

Product rule $$\frac{\mathrm {d} }{\mathrm {d}x}[g(x)h(x)]=g‚Äô(x)h(x)+g(x)h‚Äô(x)$$

Quotient rule$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}[\frac{g(x)}{h(x)}]=\frac{h(x)g‚Äô(x)-g(x)h‚Äô(x)}{[h(x)]^2}$$

Common derivatives

Derivatives Derivation
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(x)=1$$ $$nx^{n-1}$$ and [[Derivation of power rule]]
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\sin x)=\cos x$$ [[Derivation of trig derivatives]]
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\cos x)=-\sin x$$ Same as above
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\tan x)=\sec^2 x$$ ~
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\sec x)=\sec x \tan x$$ ~
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\csc x)=-\csc x \cot x$$ ~
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\cot x)=-\csc^2 x$$ ~
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\sin^{-1}x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}$$
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\cos^{-1}x)=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}$$
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\tan^{-1}x)=\frac{1}{1+x^2}$$
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(a^x)=a^x\ln a$$ [[Derivation of Euler‚Äôs number differentiation rule]]
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(e^x)=e^x$$ [[Euler‚Äôs number]],[[Derivation of Euler‚Äôs number differentiation rule]]
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\ln x)=\frac{1}{x}, x>0$$ Refer [Implicit differentiation]
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\ln \mid x\mid)=\frac{1}{x}, x \neq 0$$
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\log_ax)=\frac{1}{x\ln a},x>0$$

Implicit differentiation

Differentiation of implicit equations, where:

  • two or more variables are interdependent on each other

  • example: $$x^2+y^2=5$$$$\sin(x)y^2=x$$$$y=\ln(x)$$

Approach: basically differentiate then arrange

x2+y2=5d(x2+y2=5)2xdx+2ydy=02x2y=dydx\begin{aligned} &x^2+y^2=5\\ &\mathrm{d}(x^2+y^2=5)\\ &2x\mathrm{d}x + 2y\mathrm{d}y = 0\\ &\frac{2x}{2y}=\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} \end{aligned} ‚Äãx2+y2=5d(x2+y2=5)2xdx+2ydy=02y2x‚Äã=dxdy‚Äã‚Äã

sin‚Å°(x)y2=xd(sin‚Å°(x)y2)=dxcos‚Å°(x)dx‚àóy2+2ydy‚àósin‚Å°(x)=dxdydx=1‚àícos‚Å°(x)y22ysin‚Å°(x)\begin{aligned} &\sin(x)y^2=x\\ &\mathrm{d}(\sin(x)y^2)=\mathrm{d}x\\ &\cos(x)\mathrm{d}x*y^2+2y\mathrm{d}y*\sin(x)=\mathrm{d}x\\ &\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}=\frac{1-\cos(x)y^2}{2y\sin(x)} \end{aligned} ‚Äãsin(x)y2=xd(sin(x)y2)=dxcos(x)dx‚àóy2+2ydy‚àósin(x)=dxdxdy‚Äã=2ysin(x)1‚àícos(x)y2‚Äã‚Äã

y=ln‚Å°(x)ey=xd(ey)=dxeydy=dxdydx=1ey=1x\begin{aligned} &y=\ln(x)\\ &e^y=x\\ &\mathrm{d}(e^y)=\mathrm{d}x\\ &e^y\mathrm{d}y=\mathrm{d}x\\ &\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}=\frac{1}{e^y}=\frac{1}{x}\\ \end{aligned} ‚Äãy=ln(x)ey=xd(ey)=dxeydy=dxdxdy‚Äã=ey1‚Äã=x1‚Äã‚Äã

entry.title: Derivation of Euler's number
entry.content:
e = 2.71828‚Ä¶

This is what defines the magical Euler‚Äôs number:

ddx2x=2x+‚ñ≥x‚àí2x‚ñ≥x=2x(2‚ñ≥x‚àí1‚ñ≥x)2‚ñ≥x‚àí1‚ñ≥x‚âä0.6931...ddx3x=3x+‚ñ≥x‚àí3x‚ñ≥x=3x(3‚ñ≥x‚àí1‚ñ≥x)3‚ñ≥x‚àí1‚ñ≥x‚âä1.0986...::ddx8x=8x+‚ñ≥x‚àí8x‚ñ≥x=8x(8‚ñ≥x‚àí1‚ñ≥x)8‚ñ≥x‚àí1‚ñ≥x‚âä2.0794...\begin{aligned} &\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}2^x\\ &=\frac{2^{x+ \triangle x}-2^x}{\triangle x}\\ &=2^x(\frac{2^{\triangle x}-1}{\triangle x})\\ &\frac{2^{\triangle x}-1}{\triangle x}\approxeq 0.6931...\\ &\\ &\\ &\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}3^x\\ &=\frac{3^{x+ \triangle x}-3^x}{\triangle x}\\ &=3^x(\frac{3^{\triangle x}-1}{\triangle x})\\ &\frac{3^{\triangle x}-1}{\triangle x}\approxeq 1.0986...\\ &:\\ &:\\ &\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}8^x\\ &=\frac{8^{x+ \triangle x}-8^x}{\triangle x}\\ &=8^x(\frac{8^{\triangle x}-1}{\triangle x})\\ &\frac{8^{\triangle x}-1}{\triangle x}\approxeq 2.0794...\\ \end{aligned} ‚Äãdxd‚Äã2x=‚ñ≥x2x+‚ñ≥x‚àí2x‚Äã=2x(‚ñ≥x2‚ñ≥x‚àí1‚Äã)‚ñ≥x2‚ñ≥x‚àí1‚Äã‚âä0.6931...dxd‚Äã3x=‚ñ≥x3x+‚ñ≥x‚àí3x‚Äã=3x(‚ñ≥x3‚ñ≥x‚àí1‚Äã)‚ñ≥x3‚ñ≥x‚àí1‚Äã‚âä1.0986...::dxd‚Äã8x=‚ñ≥x8x+‚ñ≥x‚àí8x‚Äã=8x(‚ñ≥x8‚ñ≥x‚àí1‚Äã)‚ñ≥x8‚ñ≥x‚àí1‚Äã‚âä2.0794...‚Äã

In the sequence above,it is found out that the derivative of a base to the power of a variable is: $$base^{variable} \times constant$$

When the base is e, the constant = 1

ddxex=ex+‚ñ≥x‚àíex‚ñ≥x=ex(e‚ñ≥x‚àí1‚ñ≥x)e‚ñ≥x‚àí1‚ñ≥x‚âä1.000...\begin{aligned} &\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}e^x\\ &=\frac{e^{x+ \triangle x}-e^x}{\triangle x}\\ &=e^x(\frac{e^{\triangle x}-1}{\triangle x})\\ &\frac{e^{\triangle x}-1}{\triangle x}\approxeq 1.000...\\ \end{aligned} ‚Äãdxd‚Äãex=‚ñ≥xex+‚ñ≥x‚àíex‚Äã=ex(‚ñ≥xe‚ñ≥x‚àí1‚Äã)‚ñ≥xe‚ñ≥x‚àí1‚Äã‚âä1.000...‚Äã

entry.title: Derivation of derivative rules
entry.content:
These messy stuff provide simple understanding of how the differentiation formulas are derived, makes memorizing the formulas easier for me, and made me able to derive some of the formulas by myself, which is very useful when you are a forgetful person.

Power rule

Simple expansion of (x + change of x)^n

(x+dx)n=(x+dx)(x+dx)(x+dx)...(x+dx)=xn+nxn‚àí1dx(x+dx)^n=(x+dx)(x+dx)(x+dx)...(x+dx)\newline=x^n+nx^{n-1}dx (x+dx)n=(x+dx)(x+dx)(x+dx)...(x+dx)=xn+nxn‚àí1dx

there will be multiples of dx^2 from the expansion but is negligible cause the value of dx^2 is too small
x^n :derived out simply
x^(n-1) :derived as following:

xn‚àí1dx=(dx‚àóx...x)+(x‚àódx...x)+...(x‚àóx...dx)x^{n-1}dx=(dx*x...x)+(x*dx...x)+...(x*x...dx) xn‚àí1dx=(dx‚àóx...x)+(x‚àódx...x)+...(x‚àóx...dx)

there is n times of (dx * x ‚Ä¶* x), thus:

nxn‚àí1nx^{n-1} nxn‚àí1

Chain rule

Derivation 1:

ddx[g(h(x))]\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}[g(h(x))] dxd‚Äã[g(h(x))]

Let h(x) = y

d(g(y))=g‚Ä≤(y)dy\mathrm{d}(g(y))=g'(y) \mathrm{d}y d(g(y))=g‚Ä≤(y)dy

Substitute y with h(x)

g‚Ä≤(y)d(h(x))=g‚Ä≤(h(x))h‚Ä≤(x)dxg'(y) \mathrm{d}(h(x))=g'(h(x))h'(x)\mathrm{d}x g‚Ä≤(y)d(h(x))=g‚Ä≤(h(x))h‚Ä≤(x)dx

Derivation 2:

dzdx=dzdy√ódydx\frac{\mathrm {d}z}{\mathrm {d}x}=\frac{\mathrm {d}z}{\mathrm {d}y}\times \frac{\mathrm {d}y}{\mathrm {d}x} dxdz‚Äã=dydz‚Äã√ódxdy‚Äã

Other rules involved:

  • [Power rule]

Product rule

\begin{split} &\frac{\mathrm {d}}{\mathrm {d}x}g(x)h(x)=\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{g(x+\triangle x)h(x+\triangle x)-g(x)h(x)}{\triangle x}\\ &=\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{g(x)[h(x+\triangle x)-h(x)]+h(x+\triangle x)[g(x+\triangle x)-g(x)]}{\triangle x}\\ &=\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{[g(x)h(x+\triangle x)-g(x)h(x+\triangle x)]+g(x+\triangle x)h(x+\triangle x)-g(x)h(x)}{\triangle x}\\ &= (\lim_{\triangle x \rightarrow 0}\frac{g(x)}{\triangle x}\times \lim_{\triangle x \rightarrow 0}\frac{h(x+\triangle x)-h(x)}{\triangle x}) +(\lim_{\triangle x \rightarrow 0}\frac{h(x+\triangle x)}{\triangle x}\times \lim_{\triangle x \rightarrow 0}\frac{g(x+\triangle x)-g(x)}{\triangle x})\\ &=g'(x)h(x)+g(x)h'(x) \end{split}

Geometric illustration:

Other rules involved:

  • [First principle]

Quotient rule

ddx[g(x)h‚àí1(x)]=g‚Ä≤(x)h‚àí1(x)+g(x)[ddxh‚àí1(x)]=g‚Ä≤(x)h(x)+(‚àíg(x)h‚Ä≤(x)[h(x)]2)=g‚Ä≤(x)h(x)‚àíg(x)h‚Ä≤(x)h(x)2\begin{aligned} &\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}[g(x)h^{-1}(x)]\\ &=g'(x)h^{-1}(x)+g(x)[\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}h^{-1}(x)]\\ &=\frac{g'(x)}{h(x)}+(-\frac{g(x)h'(x)}{[h(x)]^2})\\ &=\frac{g'(x)h(x)-g(x)h'(x)}{h(x)^2} \end{aligned} ‚Äãdxd‚Äã[g(x)h‚àí1(x)]=g‚Ä≤(x)h‚àí1(x)+g(x)[dxd‚Äãh‚àí1(x)]=h(x)g‚Ä≤(x)‚Äã+(‚àí[h(x)]2g(x)h‚Ä≤(x)‚Äã)=h(x)2g‚Ä≤(x)h(x)‚àíg(x)h‚Ä≤(x)‚Äã‚Äã

Other rules involved:

  • [Power rule]
  • [Reciprocal rule]
  • [Chain rule]

Reciprocal rule

lim‚Å°h‚Üí0(1f(x+h)‚àí1f(x)h)=lim‚Å°h‚Üí0(f(x)‚àíf(x+h)h‚àóf(x)f(x+h))=lim‚Å°h‚Üí0(‚àíf(x+h)‚àíf(x)h√ó1f(x)f(x+h))=‚àíf‚Ä≤(x)√ó1f(x)2=‚àíf‚Ä≤(x)f(x)2\begin{aligned} &\lim_{h\rightarrow0} (\frac{ \frac{1}{f(x+h)} - \frac{1}{f(x)}}{h})\\ &=\lim_{h\rightarrow0}(\frac{f(x)-f(x+h)}{h*f(x)f(x+h)})\\ &=\lim_{h\rightarrow0}(-\frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h}\times \frac{1}{f(x)f(x+h)})\\ &=-f'(x)\times \frac{1}{f(x)^2}=-\frac{f'(x)}{f(x)^2} \end{aligned} ‚Äãh‚Üí0lim‚Äã(hf(x+h)1‚Äã‚àíf(x)1‚Äã‚Äã)=h‚Üí0lim‚Äã(h‚àóf(x)f(x+h)f(x)‚àíf(x+h)‚Äã)=h‚Üí0lim‚Äã(‚àíhf(x+h)‚àíf(x)‚Äã√óf(x)f(x+h)1‚Äã)=‚àíf‚Ä≤(x)√óf(x)21‚Äã=‚àíf(x)2f‚Ä≤(x)‚Äã‚Äã

Other rule involved:

  • [First principle]

Trigonometry derivatives

lim‚Å°Œ∏‚Üí0sinŒ∏Œ∏=1\lim_{\theta \rightarrow 0}\frac{sin \theta}{\theta}=1 Œ∏‚Üí0lim‚ÄãŒ∏sinŒ∏‚Äã=1

lim‚Å°Œ∏‚Üí0cosŒ∏‚àí1Œ∏=0\lim_{\theta \rightarrow 0}\frac{cos \theta-1}{\theta}=0 Œ∏‚Üí0lim‚ÄãŒ∏cosŒ∏‚àí1‚Äã=0

[[Proof of trig limits]]

sin

ddx(sin‚Å°(x))=lim‚Å°h‚Üí0sin‚Å°(x+h)‚àísin‚Å°xh\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm {d}x}(\sin(x))=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{\sin(x+h)-\sin x}{h} dxd‚Äã(sin(x))=h‚Üí0lim‚Äãhsin(x+h)‚àísinx‚Äã

From [[Trig identity]]: $$\sin(x+h)=\sin(x)\cos(h)+\cos(x)\sin(h)$$

lim‚Å°h‚Üí0sin‚Å°(x)cos‚Å°(h)+cos‚Å°(x)sin‚Å°(h)‚àísin‚Å°(x)h=lim‚Å°h‚Üí0sin‚Å°(x)(cos‚Å°(h)‚àí1)+cos‚Å°(x)sin‚Å°(h)h=lim‚Å°h‚Üí0sin‚Å°(x)cos‚Å°(h)‚àí1h+lim‚Å°h‚Üí0cos‚Å°(x)sin‚Å°(h)h=sin‚Å°(x)(0)+cos‚Å°(x)(1)=cos‚Å°(x)\begin{aligned} &\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{\sin(x)\cos(h)+\cos(x)\sin(h)-\sin(x)}{h}\\ &=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{\sin(x)(\cos(h)-1)+\cos(x)\sin(h)}{h}\\ &=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\sin(x)\frac{\cos(h)-1}{h}+\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\cos(x)\frac{\sin(h)}{h}\\ &=\sin(x)(0)+\cos(x)(1)\\ &=\cos(x) \end{aligned} ‚Äãh‚Üí0lim‚Äãhsin(x)cos(h)+cos(x)sin(h)‚àísin(x)‚Äã=h‚Üí0lim‚Äãhsin(x)(cos(h)‚àí1)+cos(x)sin(h)‚Äã=h‚Üí0lim‚Äãsin(x)hcos(h)‚àí1‚Äã+h‚Üí0lim‚Äãcos(x)hsin(h)‚Äã=sin(x)(0)+cos(x)(1)=cos(x)‚Äã

cos

ddx(cos‚Å°(x))=lim‚Å°h‚Üí0cos‚Å°(x+h)‚àícos‚Å°(x)h\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\cos(x))=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{\cos(x+h)-\cos(x)}{h} dxd‚Äã(cos(x))=h‚Üí0lim‚Äãhcos(x+h)‚àícos(x)‚Äã

From [[Trig identity]]:

cos‚Å°(x+h)=cos‚Å°(x)cos‚Å°(h)‚àísin‚Å°(x)sin‚Å°(h)\cos(x+h)=\cos(x)\cos(h)-\sin(x)\sin(h) cos(x+h)=cos(x)cos(h)‚àísin(x)sin(h)

lim‚Å°h‚Üí0cos‚Å°(x)cos‚Å°(h)‚àísin‚Å°(x)sin‚Å°(h)‚àícos‚Å°(x)h=lim‚Å°h‚Üí0cos‚Å°(x)(cos‚Å°(h)‚àí1)‚àísin‚Å°(x)sin‚Å°(h)h=lim‚Å°h‚Üí0cos‚Å°(x)cos‚Å°(h)‚àí1h‚àílim‚Å°h‚Üí0sin‚Å°(x)sin‚Å°(h)h=cos‚Å°(x)(0)‚àísin‚Å°(x)(1)=‚àísin‚Å°(x)\begin{aligned} &\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{\cos(x)\cos(h)-\sin(x)\sin(h)-\cos(x)}{h}\\ &=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{\cos(x)(\cos(h)-1)-\sin(x)\sin(h)}{h}\\ &=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\cos(x)\frac{\cos(h)-1}{h}-\lim_{h \rightarrow 0}\frac{\sin(x)\sin(h)}{h}\\ &=\cos(x)(0)-\sin(x)(1)=-\sin(x)\\ \end{aligned} ‚Äãh‚Üí0lim‚Äãhcos(x)cos(h)‚àísin(x)sin(h)‚àícos(x)‚Äã=h‚Üí0lim‚Äãhcos(x)(cos(h)‚àí1)‚àísin(x)sin(h)‚Äã=h‚Üí0lim‚Äãcos(x)hcos(h)‚àí1‚Äã‚àíh‚Üí0lim‚Äãhsin(x)sin(h)‚Äã=cos(x)(0)‚àísin(x)(1)=‚àísin(x)‚Äã

tan

ddx(tan‚Å°(x))=ddx(sin‚Å°(x)cos‚Å°(x))\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\tan(x))=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\frac{\sin(x)}{\cos(x)}) dxd‚Äã(tan(x))=dxd‚Äã(cos(x)sin(x)‚Äã)

From [[Trig identity]]:

cos‚Å°2(x)+sin‚Å°2(x)=1\cos^2(x)+\sin^2(x)=1 cos2(x)+sin2(x)=1

cos‚Å°(x)cos‚Å°(x)‚àísin‚Å°(x)[‚àísin‚Å°(x)]cos‚Å°2(x)=1cos‚Å°2(x)=sec‚Å°2(x)\begin{aligned} &\frac{\cos(x)\cos(x)-\sin(x)[-\sin(x)]}{\cos^2(x)}\\ &=\frac{1}{\cos^2(x)}\\ &=\sec^2(x)\\ \end{aligned} ‚Äãcos2(x)cos(x)cos(x)‚àísin(x)[‚àísin(x)]‚Äã=cos2(x)1‚Äã=sec2(x)‚Äã

quotient rule used, refer [[Derivatives]]

cot

ddx(cot‚Å°x)=ddx(cos‚Å°(x)sin‚Å°(x))\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\cot x)=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)}) dxd‚Äã(cotx)=dxd‚Äã(sin(x)cos(x)‚Äã)

cos‚Å°(x)cos‚Å°(x)‚àí[‚àísin‚Å°(x)sin‚Å°(x)]sin‚Å°2(x)=1sin‚Å°2(x)=csc‚Å°2(x)\begin{aligned} &\frac{\cos(x)\cos(x)-[-\sin(x)\sin(x)]}{\sin^2(x)}\\ &=\frac{1}{\sin^2(x)}\\ &=\csc^2(x)\\ \end{aligned} ‚Äãsin2(x)cos(x)cos(x)‚àí[‚àísin(x)sin(x)]‚Äã=sin2(x)1‚Äã=csc2(x)‚Äã

sec

ddx(sec‚Å°(x))=ddx(1cos‚Å°(x))\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\sec(x))=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\frac{1}{\cos(x)}) dxd‚Äã(sec(x))=dxd‚Äã(cos(x)1‚Äã)

‚àí(‚àísin‚Å°(x)cos‚Å°2(x))=sin‚Å°(x)cos‚Å°(x)√ó1cos‚Å°(x)=tan‚Å°(x)sec‚Å°(x)\begin{aligned} &-(\frac{-\sin(x)}{\cos^2(x)})\\ &=\frac{\sin(x)}{\cos(x)}\times \frac{1}{\cos(x)}\\ &=\tan(x)\sec(x) \end{aligned} ‚Äã‚àí(cos2(x)‚àísin(x)‚Äã)=cos(x)sin(x)‚Äã√ócos(x)1‚Äã=tan(x)sec(x)‚Äã

reciprocal rule used, refer [[Derivatives]]

cosec

ddx(csc‚Å°(x))=ddx(1sin‚Å°(x))\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\csc(x))=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\frac{1}{\sin(x)}) dxd‚Äã(csc(x))=dxd‚Äã(sin(x)1‚Äã)

‚àí(cos‚Å°(x)sin‚Å°2(x))=‚àí(cos‚Å°(x)sin‚Å°(x))(1sin‚Å°(x))=‚àícsc‚Å°(x)cot‚Å°(x)\begin{aligned} &-(\frac{\cos(x)}{\sin^2(x)})\\ &=-(\frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)})(\frac{1}{\sin(x)})\\ &=-\csc(x)\cot(x)\\ \end{aligned} ‚Äã‚àí(sin2(x)cos(x)‚Äã)=‚àí(sin(x)cos(x)‚Äã)(sin(x)1‚Äã)=‚àícsc(x)cot(x)‚Äã

reciprocal rule used, refer [[Derivatives]]

entry.title: Chemistry experiments
entry.content:
Noting down 2023 foundation chemistry experiments. (Excellent academic integrity)

Analysis of vinegar

Equations: $$\mathrm{CH_3COOH+NaOH}\rightarrow\mathrm{CH_3COONa+H_2O}$$

Neutralisation reaction

Precautions

  • Titrate slowly
  • Use white paper as background
  • Eye maintain parallel with meniscus when taking reading to avoid parallax error

Formula $$0.003\times\mathrm{A.Titre}$$

Anyway this was our first failed experiment, the content of vingear was way too high, perhaps we did the titrations too fast.

Analysis of bleach

Equations:

$$\mathrm{OCl^- + 2I^- + 2H^+}\rightarrow\mathrm{I_2 + Cl^- + H_2O}$$

  • Oxidizing agent: hypochlorite ion
  • Reducing agent: iodide ion and hydrogen ion

$$\mathrm{I_2 + 2S_2O_3^‚Äú2-‚Äù} \rightarrow \mathrm{S_4O_6^‚Äú2-‚Äù + 2I^-}$$

  • Oxidizing agent: iodine
  • Reducing agent: thiosulphate ion

Precautions

  • Pls invert the volumetric flask to produce homogenous solution
  • With each addition of thiosulfate, the concentration of I2¬†decreases, and the brown colour will fade to a pale yellow colour then to colourless, making detection of the end point difficult, thus, a small amount of starch is added near the endpoint, in order to form a deep blue complex with iodine that is easy to observe
  • Eyes must maintain parallel with meniscus when taking reading to avoid parallax error
  • Rinse the apparatus with correct solution

Formula $$\frac{[(\frac{\mathrm{A.Titre}\div1000\times 0.1}{2})\div 0.02]\times 250\times74.45}{200}$$

Expected result: 5%
Expected average titre: around 21.5

Percentage of error $$\frac{\mid \mathrm{theory-result}\mid}{\mathrm{theory}}$$

Discussion

  • back titration is performed to reduce the volume of titrant needed to complete decolourise the titrate
  • Put potassium iodide and sulphuric acid in immediately without leaving them out in the open air

Chromatography of inks

Precautions

  • make sure inner wall of beaker is dry
  • be careful
  • watch glass placed concave Âáπ outwards (prevent particles from entering)
  • stop when liquid is 1cm from top of paper (be consistent with this)
  • IMMEDIATELY record the level with pencil
  • IMMEDIATELY put to entrance of fume chamber to
  • IMMEDIATELY circle the spot when paper is dry
  • For food dye, let spot dry then dip again

Retention value formula: $$R_f = \frac{\text{traveldistance_component}}{\text{traveldistance_solvent}}$$

Factors affecting rate of reaction

Chemical equilibrium

Precaution

  • be honest and trust the result
  • handle cuvette carefully don‚Äôt stain the transparent side

Data analysis

  1. Find concentration of Fe3+ and SCN- in each of the solutions.
  2. Find the concentration of FeSCN2+ at equilibrium using ratio of its absorbance against the standard FeSCN2+ solution absorbance: $$\mathrm{FeSCN^{2+}}{(eq)} = \mathrm{M_standard} \times \frac{abs{solution}}{abs_{standard}}$$
  3. Calculate the concentration of Fe3+ and SCN- at equilibrium using ICE method: $$\begin{aligned} \&\mathrm{Fe^{3+}}{eq}=\mathrm{FeSCN^{2+}}{eq} - \mathrm{Fe^{3+}}{0} \&\mathrm{SCN^{-}}{eq}=\mathrm{FeSCN^{2+}}{eq} - \mathrm{SCN^{-}}{0} \end{aligned}$$
  4. Calculate the equilibrium constant: $$\mathrm{K_c} = \frac{[\mathrm{FeSCN^{2+}}{eq}]}{[\mathrm{Fe^{3+}}{eq}][\mathrm{SCN^{-}}_{eq}]}$$

I was Âßî‰ª•Èáç‰ªª to determine the disappearance of the X mark, yet I failed almost everytime because I didn‚Äôt blink during the observation and somehow the mark faded away from my view faster than it actually was. Nevertheless, it was ok.

Acid base equilibrium

7A: pH value of strong and weak acid

  • strong acid ionises completely in water
  • weak acid ionises partially in water

7B: buffer solutions

  • buffer solution is made by mixing weak acid with its conjugate base, forming a system of dynamic equilibrium
  • when acid is added, the conjugate base amount is reduce because it accepted the protons,
    • thus the system shifts to right, produce more base, indirectly minimizing pH change
  • when base is added, the weak acid reacts with the hydroxide ions, decreasing in amount
    • thus the system shifts to left, producing more weak acid, indirectly minimizing the pH change

Precautions

  • Careful with dilutions
  • Rinse apparatus before dilute
  • Rinse pH meter‚Äôs probe everytime after/before use

This time my brain ËøõÊ∞¥, putting the probe back in its solution everytime after use. I was not supposed to do that. Fortunately, the consequence was small because the solution was a buffer. Thank god everything turned out well, and we got the highest mark for our report in this semester (3.5/3.75) üòé
